title: What are the disadvantages of being multilingual? - Quora

response.answer_text: Mother tongue: Kannada Language of education: English Other languages: Hindi, Telugu, Punjabi (in bits), Sanskrit (in pieces) Learning stage: German Here are my problems: I mix the languages.Communication is an utter delight if you know the exact same languages as I do. Why? Because I can mix the languages so easily that I could probably do it in my sleep! But otherwise, it’s painful. Maaro (‘Beat up’ in Hindi) + Fy (as in stupe’fy’) = Maarofy (The act of beating up) Call + Thini (borrowed from maad’thini’ (Kannada), I’ll do it) = Callthini (I will call) I’m funny in Hindi and English.I can tell jokes in Hindi and English. I’m useless and obnoxiously boring in a group of Telugu speakers. I understand their jokes, I have trouble giving a soul satisfyingly fitting reply to their sarcasm. Not being able to retort back to sarcasm crushes my core being! I laugh at the unlikeliest of jokes.I had an entirely different expectation of Stranger things when I started watching it last year. I didn’t like it. When I saw in the tiles that it was created by Duffer Brothers, I giggled. Duffer might be a completely normal name but in Hindi it means ‘stupid’. It was created by stupid brothers, haha. I cook in Kannada and a little bit in Hindi. I’m a horrible cook in English.For instance, I have no idea what is Jeerige, Menthya, Sasive, Ingu (Kannada), Sabudana (Hindi) in English. My white friends will never believe me when I say I can cook. I need google images to explain a recipe! I get angry and I curse in Hindi and KannadaI hate goobes (owls, kannada. Used as a derogatory word for loners and socially awkward people) And when you’re being a gubald (Idiot in Kannada) and don’t understand my cuss words…Atha majhi stakli! (I know that’s Marathi but hey, let’s not restrict ourselves when it comes to anger, haha). And if you try and defend your idiotic act, battameez, chup kar! (Hindi, Rude human just shut it!) See the problem of being multilingual already? I become sad in Kannada. If you don’t understand Kannada, I’ll be more sad.I dance in Punjabi…because, duh!I preach in Sanskrit. Read this: Chinmayee Raj's answer to What are your favourite shlokas?I contemplate life in English and it’s hard to communicate to close ones because we are close enough to talk in Kannada. It’s just weird to talk to them in English...German is still in its infancy. The baby needs to learn that culture to add a new dimension to my brain!

I speak 4 languages fluently now: English, Oriya, Bengali and Hindi. I could speak in Sanskrit as well but I have lost touch with it over the past decade. The only disadvantage I can think of is sometimes literally translating idioms/phrases in one language to the other, so I often become the laughing stock in my group. An example that happened yesterday:My friend and I were driving another friend’s car who is currently out of town. We had a mean random idea to run through every red light just so that she is greeted with a ton of tickets when she comes back (we didnt). I wanted to tell my friend, a Bengali, to rush through the lights. In Oriya, that would be “Maadi ja”. I translated it to Bengali and told my friend “Mere ja” which is, uhm, “Keep killing”. And on and on it goes. When I was teaching a class this semester to undergraduate students (in USA, for context) and explaining a particularly hard topic, “matlab” (Hindi: meaning/implying) slipped out more than once. So embarrassing! I subconsciously switch between languages when I am not too careful about it. I often scramble up everything and invent a language of my own. I interact with people who speak all 4 languages, often in the same room and sometimes I find the effort of analyzing their face and switching my dialect so tiring (I’m lazy) I revert to sign language or just stay quiet. That’s about it though. I love that I can speak in 4 languages, swear in 6 and dream in countless more!

If you do it wrong, being multilingual can be horrible. Suspicion Language and tribe are not quite synonyms, but almost. People who are very tribal cannot fathom getting along with people from another ethnicity. Since they don’t relate to people from another tribe they can’t understand how you can either. They will be tempted to see you either as a traitor to your race or a spy for the enemy. Confusion Some multilingual people never really develop a mastery of any language. They can’t express themselves comfortably without code switching. Let me give you an example, Hace frío. Put a sweater on o si no, te vas a resfriar. You can’t miss work. A lot of these people suffer a crisis of identity. There is a growing literature of written code-switching between English and Spanish where the authors complain about how they don’t fit in anywhere. It Doesn’t Need to Be Like That Some multilingual people get really good at slipping between cultures. They put in the effort to speak their languages well and not get stuck in the middle. They are honest and genuine, earning the trust of people from the different groups. Being multilingual can be a totally enriching experience—but not if you put your mind on autopilot. You need to be wiling to put in the effort.

What are the disadvantages to being bilingual or multilingual? I’m sure that I already answered a similar question elsewhere, so this one is highly likely to be merged… Tongue-in-cheek disadvantages (all of which I have actually experienced): when watching entertainment wherein some character is supposed to be of some “exotic” background and speak their supposed native language, and being bothered by the fact they have the wrong accent and are speaking gibberishfinding the perfect word to use all the letters on your Scrabble rack but then realizing it’s the wrong language; by the same token, the daily Jumble puzzle is actually harder because my wife and I often see more than one solution for certain combinations of lettersthere’s a perceptible awkward moment when polyglots with different native languages meet and have to decide in which language to converseAnd one real disadvantage: in a monolingual society that prizes conformity, being overtly multilingual provides an easy pretext for being called out for being different

Maintaining a poker face when someone is saying something ridiculous in a language they don’t think you understand becomes substantially more difficult. The danger of becoming a go to 24/7 available translator for random strangers if your proficiency is in minority heightens. Concentration may be broken if you hear a language you know but haven’t heard in a while suddenly spoken nearby. Involuntary eavesdropping. Awkward exchange of solidarity even if you have nothing but language proficiency in common. When you get so engulfed in some random text and its odd direct translation to a different language that you forget that time is a thing and miss your appointment. That awkward moment when someone goes off in a language you know but most others in the group don’t and it’s now on you to either steer this person back to comprehensibility, or yet again become the translator for the evening.

Honestly, I can’t think of any! I now know the Assamese words Mom used to fire me with while I was growing upI’m part of the Malayalee group in my department! I’m also part of the Bengali and Assamese groups!I get special privileges around here: the security guards being mostly Assamese, lets me in through restricted areas past deadlines, the local Kannadiga bartender gives me extra booze every time I drop by, and the Bengalis in the institute invite me for every Bengali festivalTalk about groups, I was in the organizing committee of the Ulsoor Bengali Association Pujo, and also part of the Kamanahalli Malayalee Sangham! We had one of the grandest Onams in Bangalore!I can speak in the most fluent Hindi at a Pujo Pandal in South Calcutta, incurring the wrath of many a boudi or kakima who’d comment ei dekho, marwadi chele amader meyeder shaathe ghure beracche! (Translation: look at that! A Marwadi boy loitering around with our girls!), and just as easily switch over to the most fluent Bengali to shut them up! Kintu apnader meyeder kono apotti nei! (Translation: But then your girls aren’t complaining!)My parents used to switch to Bengali every time they wanted to discuss something secretive in front of us kids. Now, they have to go out!I can have more meaningful conversations with people from different parts of the countryI blend in well - north, south, east, west, doesn’t matter, I feel home wherever I go!Wait, this was about disadvantages! My bad! Can’t find any.

Hmm, not sure if its a disadvantage but it can lead to hilarity at times. I speak Hindi, Palakkad Tamil and can understand Malayalam to a good extent. And sometimes the words in one language have a very much opposite meaning in the other. Bear with me please as I will be using some “adult” words :P The word eruvu in Palakkad Tamil means “spicy hot”, while in Tamil it means manure. So when I said the “chutney has eruvu”, my Tamil friends had a good laugh. The word thooral in Tamil means drizzling, but in Malayalam it means loose motions. So when someone says in Tamil “mazhai thoorardhu” (its drizzling), the Mallu in me guffaws. The word “kundi” refers to the door latch in Hindi, in Tamil it refers to a woman’s private parts. So when someone says “kundi lagao” (lock the door) I am wondering whether to laugh or not. There are plenty more examples. Knowing multiple languages means one has to be aware of using such words lest you offend someone. That is the only disadvantage/hilarity I can think of.

I don’t see many disadvantages of being bilingual because I agree with the common notion that knowing many languages is an exposure to different cultures, which in turn creates a better understanding of others as well as yourself. However, I know a couple of cases where an immigrant parent enforced their native language on a child so much in their early years that english became their second language (as an American citizen) so I could see how it could become a disadvantage.

Not many actually. I speak Telugu, Hindi, English, Tamil, Basic Spanish and can understand a bit of Malayalam when spoken slowly. Was in Ahmadabad once for training in my company with a group of 20+ people with 20 people being from TN and none of them spoke Hindi. They requested me to take them around the city and me being a lazy ass hated the idea. Turned out, they were the sweetest bunch of people who later became my colleagues in couple of projects.Was in Uruguay for several months and i was always the face of the group when it comes to converse with locals for help. Damn it’s so tiresome when you’re sleepy.. I’m too lazy for it.Had to be the translator for few people in mixed groups.If i say i speak a little of Spanish, people used to expect me to translate a basic sentence and prove it which i obviously used to. But again, it’s annoying to do it over and over.I think translating stuff to people was the only disadvantage. It’s actually fun if you love it but it gets boring at times.

Once I was trying to explain how something works in Spanish grammar to my friends. I had to say a phrase in Spanish and was about to explain what I meant, and I nearly slipped back into Spanish. I will be speaking in Spanish, forget a word, and immediately think of the German equivalent (I’m learning German), and have to translate it into English and then Spanish. The disadvantage is really getting languages mixed up. It leads to confusion, frustration, and a lot of stumbling over words. But, knowing more than one language is kind of worth the disadvantage. And it’s not even that bad.

This is going to get collapsed for being short, but there are none. I don’t know why someone would think that there are, unless he is looking for an excuse not to study a language, when deep down, he knows it would really benefit him.

I can't really think of any disadvantages if you are multilingual (especially if you're perfectly fluent in the languages). The only inconvenience that comes to mind for me is that I sometimes switch between languages without realizing since I speak a mix of Hungarian and English at home. Nothing else comes to mind.

The inability to communicate. A good example would be the nation of India, that has twenty-two official languages. Before the English arrived the subcontinent was a collection of small kingdoms, often at war with each other. The English colonial period gave the Indian people a common language, which facilitates communication even today.

What are the disadvantages to being bilingual or multilingual? Honestly, I have not yet found one, though reading some of the other responses (e.g. by Severine Riise) ring a bit of a bell (e.g. the one about “awkward solidarity). Whatever they may be, the disadvantages are far outweighed by the advantages, I believe.

Interesting you should ask. I just read an article on perceiption in noisy environments; a team of researchers found that bi/trilinguals can have more difficulty in comprehending in their first language. http://www.utdallas.edu/~assmann/hcs6367/tabri_smith_chacra_pring10.pdf

I am a volunteer leader for the Boy Scouts. There is an interpreter strip for each language that you speak that you can sew on your uniform. I have a few of them on my uniform. Every once in a while somebody will come up to me and start conversing in one of the languages, mostly, I believe to test my ability. So far I have been able to pretty well handle the challenge. Sometimes, however, it can be sort of a pain.
